quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In her conversation, we dig into the most common mistakes early product managers make in their career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up a practical, practitioner-focused segment aimed at avoiding common early-career PM pitfalls.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We cover the concept of minimal lovable products versus minimal viable products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a potentially counterintuitive product development framing that contrasts MLP with the conventional MVP approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We talk about JZ's unique frameworks for road mapping and prioritization and OKRs
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights that the episode will share concrete methodologies for planning, prioritization, and goal-setting.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: her take on how to structure your first 90 days as a product leader at a new company, plus what she's learned from her wild year at WeWork.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Promises actionable onboarding guidance paired with real-world lessons from a high-volatility environment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, the best advice she's ever gotten around product and leadership and the story of Airbnb Plus and where it went wrong.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Teases a concrete case study (Airbnb Plus) and leadership advice, useful for learning from failure modes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You might be building an incredible AI product, but if you are using the same datasets as your competitors to train your models, you don't have much of an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Brave Search)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical differentiation lever for AI products: proprietary or unique data sources, not just model quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brave Search is the fastest growing search engine since Bing, and it's 100% independent from the big tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Brave Search)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete positioning/data point about Brave’s growth and independence as a potential alternative search provider.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building products with search capabilities, you're probably experiencing soaring API costs or lack of viable global alternatives to Bing or Google.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Brave Search)
quotes.context: Names two common, actionable problem areas teams can plan around when adding search to products: cost and vendor concentration risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to see what Miro is all about and how it can help your team collaborate better is not to listen to me talk about it, but to go check it out for yourself.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Miro)
quotes.context: A simple, counterintuitive go-to-market lesson: prioritize hands-on product experience over explanations.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes new PMs make
quotes.text: I think something that is really hard to untrain, but I think every human does it, is you jump to solutions.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights a core, universal PM failure mode to watch for and deliberately counteract.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes new PMs make
quotes.text: one of the biggest things I see, not just in my course but also just as a PM and some of the mistakes that you make as a PM is the idea of you get really attached to a solution, a way of implementing something that you can see in your head that you want to build.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Warns against solution/implementation attachment as a recurring trap that derails good product discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes new PMs make
quotes.text: Hey, we're going to go out there. We are not going to think at all about the thing that you want to build, but instead we're going to be focused on users and people in the real world and their problems.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete reset for discovery: suspend building instincts and orient entirely around real users and their problems.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes new PMs make
quotes.text: And the first step is to understand their problems and then understand if there's an opportunity here as opposed to, 'Hey, you want to build X thing for Y person.'
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Provides a stepwise mental model: problem understanding first, opportunity validation second, solution framing last.

quotes.topic_title: PM authority myths and influence reality
quotes.text: One of the first things I teach is you're not a CEO, you're, you're not here... You actually have very little true authority because you don't actually manage anyone.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Reframes the PM role away from formal authority, helping practitioners reset expectations and focus on how impact actually happens.

quotes.topic_title: PM authority myths and influence reality
quotes.text: A lot of it is all through influence, and so that is also a piece where you have to kind of untrain that thinking.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights influence as the core operating mechanism for PMs and calls out the mindset shift required to succeed.

quotes.topic_title: PM authority myths and influence reality
quotes.text: I do think a lot of people come into the product role thinking that I get to call the shots, I get to make the decisions, I get to decide what gets built.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Names a common misconception that leads to misalignment and frustration, useful for diagnosing early-career PM pitfalls.

quotes.topic_title: PM authority myths and influence reality
quotes.text: And really your job is not that. Your job is to understand here are the opportunities, and then you're kind of pulling together all the different possibilities and you're really editing.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Provides a practical mental model of PM work as opportunity discovery plus option curation/editing rather than decision dictatorship.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
quotes.text: And so we went really hard down the solution space. We essentially were like, "Let's go inspect our inventory, let's actually try to manage our inventory more." And really what we should have done is taken a step back and be like, "What's the real problem? The real problem is people want to know what they're getting themselves into. We need to represent the homes a lot better."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A clear reminder to avoid solution-first thinking and reframe initiatives around the underlying user problem.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
quotes.text: And I think the other piece here that's really important is, what, as a company is your strategic strength and what's in your wheelhouse? So for example, Airbnb, we weren't that strong in operations. Again, we're this platform with this marketplace. And so if you don't have that muscle and then you're asking the company, the teams to essentially build it from the ground up, that's really, really difficult. Not to mention the unit economics, are the unit economics actually going to work even as you scale?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical lens for product strategy: align bets with core strengths and validate operational feasibility and unit economics early.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
quotes.text: I think you actually need to really make sure that unit economics work quite at the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Counterbalances “we’ll figure it out at scale” thinking by emphasizing early unit-economics validation.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
quotes.text: If you're trying to achieve this idea of really knowing the quality of the place, and for a platform like Airbnb, the right way to go about doing is through our reviews, through our guest reviews, which are essentially free as opposed to literally sending out inspectors.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable, platform-native mechanism (reviews) versus expensive operational approaches (inspection).

quotes.topic_title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
quotes.text: So for example, it is actually cheaper to go send everyone a lockbox than to deploy an inspector and go look at your property.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete example of targeting the root cause with a cheaper intervention instead of a blunt, ops-heavy solution.

quotes.topic_title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
quotes.text: I think it's really important for every company to be dreaming big. If you don't have a big vision, it's really hard for you to innovate, but you got to couple that really big vision with thoughtfulness around your execution.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A crisp principle for balancing ambitious vision with disciplined execution so big ideas don’t become reckless bets.

quotes.topic_title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
quotes.text: So I think it's totally fine to be like, "Hey, we are going to try X for six months, three months, whatever it is, and we're explicitly going to go learn these types of things.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Introduces an explicit “learning phase” model with timeboxed experiments and defined learning goals.

quotes.topic_title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
quotes.text: And you can do what I call unscalable things in that prototyping phase, in that early phase to go learn those lessons.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Encourages intentionally unscalable prototypes early to accelerate learning before committing to scalable execution.

quotes.topic_title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
quotes.text: You should articulate what success looks like and the milestones you want to hit in the small intervals that I talked about.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical mechanism to prevent sunk-cost traps by defining success criteria and checkpoints upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
quotes.text: It's like, what is the quarter long milestone? Okay, what's the next quarter long milestone? And every single point, what is a go and no-go?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete go/no-go milestone cadence that operationalizes decision-making and makes stopping easier.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
quotes.text: I think first it comes down to your conviction. Do you actually have conviction that this is a bad idea or are you personally still learning?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for when to push back vs. treat a founder-led idea as a learning opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
quotes.text: Right. I think if you're at the point, if you're like, "I have total conviction," then your job is to say, no, you really... If you do not, you're not doing your job.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A clear accountability standard for product leaders: strong conviction obligates direct disagreement.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
quotes.text: And there what I would say is it's understanding the spirit of what they're trying to achieve.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model—align on the underlying goal (“spirit”) before debating solutions.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
quotes.text: Remind them of that, get aligned on that. And then come back with better options.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: An actionable pushback playbook: align on goals first, then propose superior alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
quotes.text: When you come back with a much better solution and you have the data and you have the thinking behind it's very rare that someone will be like, "I still want to go after this solution despite the fact that it's not working and you proposed a much better path forward."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A pragmatic observation that data-backed, better options usually beat entrenched opinions—even from founders.

quotes.topic_title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
quotes.text: The reason I care so much about minimal lovable product is because I do think in a world where there are so many different options, it's hard to just feel like, "Hey, use this thing. It barely meets a quality bar."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights why MVP thinking can fail when users have many alternatives and higher expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
quotes.text: And so I think this idea of actually deeply understanding for the thing that you're working on, what is a lovable experience? What is the quality bar that resonates with your users?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Frames MLP as a user-calibrated quality bar rather than a fixed checklist of features.

quotes.topic_title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
quotes.text: Minimal lovable products is the new MVP. The new minimal viable product.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that challenges the default “ship the bare minimum” playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
quotes.text: So there's a world where your quality bar, your "Quality bar," or let's call it your polished bar, can be a little bit lower because the reality is the thing that you're "Competing against" or you're replacing is literally a manual workflow. It's like spreadsheets. It's doing something in a super terrible way.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Gives a practical benchmark: set the bar relative to what users do today (e.g., spreadsheets/manual workflows).

quotes.topic_title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
quotes.text: So for example, a designer might have a lot higher of a bar of like "This is the kind of workflow I want, this is the kind of bar for my product." But again, someone sitting on the finance team or the IT team, their bar might be like, "Oh, I'm used to doing these 15 things and so your thing is just a lot better."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Shows how “lovable” varies by persona—different user groups have different tolerance and quality expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
quotes.text: And what we realized at the end of the day after investing in these areas, we were like, "Hey, we can get to minimal viable, but we don't know if we can actually get to minimal lovable in a way that our users really, really want. And so does it make sense for us to continue to go down this path of continues to chip away to get to minimal lovable when we are maybe hitting diminishing returns for our user base? Or does it actually make sense to release what we have but then encourage our ecosystem to contribute the lovable piece?"
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete decision framework for when to stop polishing in-house and instead lean on an ecosystem to add “lovable” layers.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
quotes.text: And then even within the feature set, it's very much a how do we do some things well as opposed to do a little bit of everything?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: focus on a smaller set of capabilities and execute them exceptionally well to reach “lovable.”

quotes.topic_title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
quotes.text: To me it's better to do five things instead of the 15 things in a really, really great way with a high degree of polish with a, "Oh, this really meets my need," versus trying to do everything and just doing a little bit of everything.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb that challenges breadth-first MVP thinking in favor of polished depth.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
quotes.text: I'll give you a very small example again, just from Webflow, this idea of keyboard shortcuts, feels small, but that is a piece that creates a lot of love from user base who are power users.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A specific example of “lovable” coming from targeted quality-of-life improvements for core users.

quotes.topic_title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
quotes.text: And so at the end of the day, you can't just keep investing, keep investing because it's going to push out your launch timeline, but can you pick a few different areas where you're like, "I'm going to scatter that pixie dust, I'm going to do a little bit more than what users are expecting"?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical approach to delight: selectively invest in a few high-impact moments rather than trying to “delight” everywhere.

quotes.topic_title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
quotes.text: So for road mapping, my biggest thing that I tell my teams is "You're telling a story. So what I want from you is I want themes, I want a story. Why are these things the biggest things to invest in these levers, the biggest ones to pull?"
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A clear mental model for roadmaps as narrative + themes rather than a list of projects.

quotes.topic_title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
quotes.text: And what I really don't want, what I think is a very common mistake from road mapping is people thinking a spreadsheet with a bunch of projects, the RICE framework, everything has an impact, a cost and an effort column filled out. They think that is prioritization and that is a roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Contrarian critique of spreadsheet/RICE-driven roadmaps being mistaken for actual prioritization and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
quotes.text: But what people, what humans really crave is like, "Why am I doing this body of work?"
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights the motivational and alignment function of a roadmap: explaining the why, not just the what.

quotes.topic_title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
quotes.text: So skating at that level is really, really critical, I think for a roadmap as opposed to going down to the really granular details of the how.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to stay at the theme/story level and let teams fill in execution details.

quotes.topic_title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
quotes.text: And then linking out, again, not even to a spreadsheet, but linking out to the artifacts and the systems that your team actually uses. So if your team uses Jira, go ahead and link out to Jira because so often docs get out of... Or spreadsheets get out of date, because they're like a snapshot of whatever it is that you needed at that point in time.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical methodology for keeping roadmaps current by linking narrative docs to live systems of record (e.g., Jira).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Teams who use Superhuman spend half the time in their inboxes respond to twice the number of emails and save over four hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Superhuman)
quotes.context: Concrete performance claims that quantify the productivity impact of changing email tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Superhuman, you can split your inbox into streams for VIPs, team members and emails from your favorite products to reduce context switching and make sure you never miss an important email.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Superhuman)
quotes.context: Actionable workflow tactic: segmenting inbound work to reduce context switching and improve prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can set reminders if you don't hear back so that you can follow up and never drop the ball on an email thread.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Superhuman)
quotes.context: Practical execution habit: using reminders to ensure reliable follow-through on open loops.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also work faster than ever before with powerful AI features like writing, editing, summarizing and even translating.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Superhuman)
quotes.context: Highlights specific AI-assisted workflows that can compress time spent on common communication tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
quotes.text: I think it's really important to become really good at and also known for something.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A simple career-acceleration framework: build a clear “superpower” that becomes your reputation inside the company.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
quotes.text: Find something that you can be really, really good at. And the reason I give that advice is because when you do that, you can crush the projects that you get. Because you're making a name for yourself, reputation, and then you are giving more responsibility. People tend to flock and give responsibility to the people that are known for being excellent at something.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism: excellence → reputation → bigger scope and more responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
quotes.text: I would say early on in my career, it was actually the fact that I had a strong analytics background.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete example of a “superpower” (analytics) used to stand out despite lacking CS/design background.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
quotes.text: But it has evolved in my career. I think that at the beginning of your career, you do want to lean into some of these pieces. It makes sense, but also even when you start to manage, it shifts dramatically. Being known as the best executor is not necessarily the thing that gives you and your team the most responsibility.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point: what gets you promoted early (execution) may not be what scales your impact as a manager.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
quotes.text: PMs have to get shit done. Yeah, ultimately you're responsible for the outcome just no matter what happens.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of PM accountability: outcomes are your responsibility regardless of circumstances.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
quotes.text: My biggest tip on OKRs is actually get really, really crisp on qualitatively. What would make you say "Yes, we did a great job"?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical starting point for OKRs: define qualitative success first to prevent fear-driven metric games.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
quotes.text: And so it's less about I would rather have all the OKRs be red or yellow and we missed everything and we learned around why we missed it than everything to be green. In fact, when everything's green, you're like, "We definitely did not set ambitious enough OKRs."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A counterintuitive stance that reframes OKR “failure” as evidence of ambition and learning, not poor performance.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
quotes.text: And so that is the worst outcome in my head where your OKRs, you're almost like doing OKRs for the sake of OKRs, as opposed to letting them be a guide to delivering really great product to your end customer.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A warning against OKR theater: hitting goals that don’t translate into meaningful user or business impact.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
quotes.text: Your job is to dream big and also have a plan to go tackle it.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A simple performance bar for PMs: ambition must be paired with an execution path, not just aspiration.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
quotes.text: This is my North Star. I'm not going to be able to do that in a quarter, that just is unreasonable, but here are the five milestones," whatever number, some number of milestones "That it's going to take me to do quarter over quarter to achieve this really, really ambitious thing. And let me draw you that path. Here's the milestone all the way across, and this is the first one. This is why it's so meaningful."
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for ambitious OKRs: articulate a North Star and map it into milestone-based quarterly progress.

quotes.topic_title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
quotes.text: The people lesson I learned was just really around empathy.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights empathy as the core leadership skill when guiding teams through volatility and uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
quotes.text: And the second lesson really was around not over-hiring.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A clear, practitioner-relevant takeaway about scaling teams responsibly to avoid painful layoffs later.

quotes.topic_title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
quotes.text: How are we really clear about, again, these milestones of we got to get through these gates, we got to be able to show these types of results, and then we unlock hiring in X, Y, Z ways? That hygiene is really, really important.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Offers a concrete hiring framework: tie headcount growth to milestone “gates” and demonstrated results.

quotes.topic_title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
quotes.text: At the end of the day, it's about booking. And yes, there's technology that would accelerate that, but do we need it to be super platform aware? Do we need it to be super futuristic? That's actually not what people care about.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A counterweight to over-engineering: focus on the core user job-to-be-done rather than futuristic tech for its own sake.

quotes.topic_title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
quotes.text: So just really understanding, again, you can still dream really big, but you don't have to dream big and hire big in all the things in order to have a very ambitious vision that you deliver to the market.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Memorable guidance that separates ambitious vision from indiscriminate scaling, reinforcing disciplined resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
quotes.text: I personally joined for the product, but I stayed for the people you joined because you're like, "I want to work on this mission. This product is really motivating." And then you really stay for the people.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A practical retention mental model: mission/product attracts talent, but people are what keep them.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
quotes.text: The thing I was wrestling with is I hired a lot of these people and I felt really responsible for the fact that I convinced them to come to this company that now was going through a lot of change.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: Highlights an operator’s accountability mindset: hiring creates an ongoing responsibility, especially during volatility.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
quotes.text: Am I going to take this new role or am I going to put myself on a layoff list essentially and give the role to someone else on the team?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A concrete, high-stakes example of values-based decision-making under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
quotes.text: That to me just really stood out and goes back to this concept around leadership is so much about empathy and people as much as it's about understanding your market, your customers, and the strategy of your product.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A leadership framework that balances product strategy with empathy as an equally core competency.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
quotes.text: I went through an interview process. I was in my second trimester and then ultimately I chose to join Webflow and I joined when I was literally at the beginning of my third trimester. So I had exactly 90 days before my first son was born.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang
quotes.context: A specific, memorable example of executing a time-boxed career transition under tight personal constraints.
